sections.title: Nervous about dental treatment?
sections.body:
Feeling anxious about dental visits is extremely common — and it shows up in different ways.

Some people feel tense before appointments. Others avoid booking altogether. Some cope until something hurts, then worry about what they’ll be told. None of that is unusual, and none of it needs justifying.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, we take dental anxiety seriously — without making it the centre of the appointment.
bullets: Clear explanations and a steady pace

sections.title: Anxiety looks different for different people
items: Worry about pain or loss of control
Sensitivity to sounds, smells, or sensations
Fear of judgement or being rushed
Concern about costs or unexpected treatment

sections.title: A calmer way of working
items: We explain what we’re doing before we do it
We agree signals to pause or stop
We avoid surprises and check in as we go
We take time where it’s needed
We work with anxiety quietly and respectfully

sections.title: Taking things at your pace
sections.body:
For nervous patients, treatment doesn’t have to happen all at once.

In many cases, it helps to start with a conversation or examination only, break treatment into shorter appointments, stabilise problems before addressing everything, and build familiarity with the team and environment.

You stay in control of the pace. Nothing is rushed by default.
bullets: Start with a conversation or examination only
Build familiarity with the team and environment

sections.title: Support options when anxiety is significant
sections.strapline: For some people, extra support helps — longer appointments, staged planning, or sedation where appropriate, assessed carefully.

sections.title: A first appointment doesn’t have to mean treatment
items: Booking an appointment doesn’t commit you to anything
The first visit can be a conversation and assessment only
It’s fine if no treatment happens at the first visit
You can choose the pace for any next steps

sections.title: Pain control and comfort
sections.body:
Modern dentistry allows for effective pain control when treatment is needed.

We’ll always discuss what you’re likely to feel, how discomfort is managed, when numbness is used, and what to expect afterwards.

If something doesn’t feel right, we stop and adjust. Comfort is part of good care.
bullets: We explain what you’re likely to feel before we start
We explain how numbness is used and what to expect afterwards
If something doesn’t feel right, we stop and adjust
